results.title: Seachange = Sea change. Series 1. Ep. 8-13
results.creator_credit: Artist Services, ABC-TV (Australia) and Sally Ayre-Smith
results.brief_description: Episodes 8-13 of the captivating series “Sea Change” set in the idyllic coastal town of Pearl Bay. The episodes included are “My Own Sweetheart” (directed by Sue Brooks), “Balls and Friggin Goodluck” and “The Accidental Activist” (both directed by Mandy Smith) and “Love Me Or Leave Me”, “Perchance To Dream” and “Sex, Death and Bridges” (directed by Paul Moloney). The series excels not only because of the great writing but the wonderful gallery of characters created by an excellent cast. Stars Sigrid Thornton, David Wenham and John Howard with guest appearances by Bill Hunter, Robert Grubb, Trudy Hellier, Jeremy Callaghan and John Flaus.

results.title: Seachange = Sea change. Series 1. Ep. 1-7
results.creator_credit: Artist Services, ABC-TV (Australia), Sally Ayre-Smith, Michael Carson, Ray Argall, Ali Ali and Sue Brooks
results.brief_description: Corporate lawyer Laura Gibson (Sigrid Thornton), and her two children find themselves moving from the city to the country when Laura’s marriage falls apart, her husband is imprisoned for embezzlement, and Laura misses out on a partnership. Reluctantly, and with dreams of picking up her life of disarray she begins a position as magistrate in the seaside community of Pearl Bay. They discover that the idyllic location harbours secrets which manifests itself in strange machinations. This tape includes the first seven episodes and stars Sigrid Thornton, David Wenham, John Howard, Bruce Alexander, Kate Atkinson, Kerry Armstrong, and Alice Garner. Episodes directed by Michael Carson, Ray Argall, Ali Ali and Sue Brooks.

results.title: Sea wife
results.creator_credit: Andre Hakim, Bob McNaught and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Cast adrift during wartime in the Indian Ocean after a bombing raid on their ship, an RAF officer (Richard Burton) and a nun (Joan Collins) in civilian clothing find themselves attracted to each other. Fighting off attacks by sharks and surviving in the harsh sun, the couple are forced together to brave the elements. The nun gives the officer no encouragement, but he falls madly in love with her and vows to find her again when they return to civilisation. Will she keep her vocation a secret or will she give in to her desires? Based on the novel ‘Sea-Wyf’ by J.M. Sott.

results.title: Sea safety
results.creator_credit: National Recording Studios and Ian Williams
results.brief_description: During the 1986 Australian premier blue water event, the Sydney to Hobart Yacht Race, crew members faced the worst weather conditions in living memory. Many yachts sought shelter, crew members were injured and one man was lost overboard. Sea-Safety Canberra, assisted by 4 fixed wing aircraft, mounted an unsuccessful search which covered more than 2,500 square kilometres. Each year Sea-Safety covers approximately 1,800 incidents, including ships running aground, cargo vessels adrift, pleasure craft in trouble. This video looks at the methods employed, and the resources available, in order to maintain efficient and prompt sea safety services to all who require them. Narrated by David Allen.

results.title: Sea road
results.brief_description: Three times a week the “Princess of Tasmania” leaves Melbourne for Devonport. Carrying up to 100 cars and 300 passengers, the ship’s crew deal efficiently and cheerfully with both people and vehicles. We see the passengers and transports loaded, overnight accommodation, and the offloading in the morning.

results.title: Sea power
results.creator_credit: Australia. Dept. of the Navy and Vincent Donovan
results.brief_description: The aircraft carrier HMAS Melbourne and the Oberon class submarine HMAS Otway take part in an exercise off the eastern coast of Australia. Also seen are the destroyer HMAS Hobart, the supply ship HMAS Stalwart, minesweepers, Navy oil tankers, patrol boats, and some of the Navy’s aircraft.

results.title: Sea in the blood
results.creator_credit: British Broadcasting Corporation and Robert Reid
results.brief_description: In Cyprus, folk history tales tell of children dying from anaemia. Village elders know that significant numbers of children have died and continue to die of a disease of the blood, called thalassemia. The video explains the incidence and treatment of thalassemia in villages of the Mediterranean. A doctor in the British Army, Colin Bate, gives accounts of the disease in Cyprus villages and specific cases are discussed. Techniques for the antenatal diagnosis of thalassemia are explained and the idea of genetic engineering is explored.
